t: Job 34
Then*p Elihu said:
“Hear*pn my words, you wise men; listen*ld to me, you men of learning.
For*ln the ear tests words as*ld the tongue tastes food.
Let*ln us discern for ourselves what is right; let*ld us learn together what is good.
“Job*pn says, ‘I am innocent, but*ld God denies me justice.
Although*ln I am right, I*ld am considered a liar; although*ln I am guiltless, his*ld arrow inflicts an incurable wound.’
Is*ln there anyone like Job, who*ld drinks scorn like water?
He*ln keeps company with evildoers; he*ld associates with the wicked.
For*ln he says, ‘There is no profit in*ld trying to please God.’
“So*pn listen to me, you men of understanding. Far*ld be it from God to do evil, from*ld the Almighty to do wrong.
He*ln repays everyone for what they have done; he*ld brings on them what their conduct deserves.
It*ln is unthinkable that God would do wrong, that*ld the Almighty would pervert justice.
Who*ln appointed him over the earth? Who*ld put him in charge of the whole world?
If*ln it were his intention and*ld he withdrew his spirit and breath,
all*ln humanity would perish together and*ld mankind would return to the dust.
“If*pn you have understanding, hear this; listen*ld to what I say.
Can*ln someone who hates justice govern? Will*ld you condemn the just and mighty One?
Is*ln he not the One who says to kings, ‘You are worthless,’ and*ld to nobles, ‘You are wicked,’
who*ln shows no partiality to princes and*ld does not favor the rich over the poor, for*ld they are all the work of his hands?
They*ln die in an instant, in the middle of the night; the*ld people are shaken and they pass away; the*ld mighty are removed without human hand.
“His*pn eyes are on the ways of mortals; he*ld sees their every step.
There*ln is no deep shadow, no utter darkness, where*ld evildoers can hide.
God*ln has no need to examine people further, that*ld they should come before him for judgment.
Without*ln inquiry he shatters the mighty and*ld sets up others in their place.
Because*ln he takes note of their deeds, he*ld overthrows them in the night and they are crushed.
He*ln punishes them for their wickedness where*ld everyone can see them,
because*ln they turned from following him and*ld had no regard for any of his ways.
They*ln caused the cry of the poor to come before him, so*ld that he heard the cry of the needy.
But*ln if he remains silent, who can condemn him? If*ld he hides his face, who can see him? Yet*ln he is over individual and nation alike,
to*ld keep the godless from ruling, from*ld laying snares for the people.
“Suppose*pn someone says to God, ‘I*ld am guilty but will offend no more.
Teach*ln me what I cannot see; if*ld I have done wrong, I will not do so again.’
Should*ln God then reward you on your terms, when*ld you refuse to repent? You*ln must decide, not I; so*ld tell me what you know.
“Men*pn of understanding declare, wise*ld men who hear me say to me,
‘Job*ln speaks without knowledge; his*ld words lack insight.’
Oh,*ln that Job might be tested to the utmost for*ld answering like a wicked man!
To*ln his sin he adds rebellion; scornfully*ld he claps his hands among us and*ld multiplies his words against God.”
